instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.SMC_LID_RIGHT: What is SMC_LID_RIGHT? SMC_LID_RIGHT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the right LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_RIGHT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.820-0928: What is 820-0928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
Hello everyone! I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that is not displaying image to the internal display. This board had some minor liquid damage near <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and was originally only giving me 5v on the charger. I replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with a new <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip and the board now gives me 20v and boots to the OS, but only displays image to an external display. I have read most of the posts here about the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>'s with no display and have already tried to replace <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> 3 times and the screen is still black. No image or backlight shows up on the screen but all the screen voltages seem to be present. External display is working fine using usb-c to HDMI adapter so not sure where to look next. The LCD connector on the board looks perfect also. Any help would be appreciated. Here are some voltage measurements I took while the board was connected to my know good test screen only.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 5.1
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PANEL_FET_EN_DLY</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_REST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> - 3.3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Are you missing image and backlight at same time?
LCD panel looks to be recognized.
Check if there is image at least.
Post exact voltage for <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>.
Did you try known good full LCD assembly?
ALso check all <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
Thanks for the welcome! I am missing both backlight and image at the same time and I have tested this board using a full assembly that I know works with another board, and it still shows nothing on internal screen. I have tried to see if there is any image on the screen using a flashlight and there is nothing. 

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> - 3.4

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
<CHIP>U9800</CHIP> could be damaged too.
This one may have firmware, I'm not sure however.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: Ok I will try that and report back. I am waiting on a stencil so I can reball that chip. I only have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board at the moment which is a 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> so I'm not sure if the <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> on that donor will work on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Should I try it anyway?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: I replaced <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> on this board with one from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor but it did not change anything. Board still boots fine to external display but wont show image or backlight on a known good LCD assembly. Do you know what else could cause this other than <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
CPU should have video output damaged then.
I don't see other reason.
Apart of possible bad solders on <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>.
Inspect for knocked off, or moved components in that area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: I inspected the area and did find 1 resistor that was soldered on sideways. It was RA821, which is the resistor for <SIGNAL>EG_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>. I checked the value of that resistor and the one next to it, which is for <SIGNAL>EG_LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> and they both measure 8.3k when the schematic shows they should be 10k. I replaced them both with new 10k resistors but they still show as 8.3k when measured on the board. I'm not sure if this means anything or not. Is there something else I can measure to confirm that the issue is with the CPU video output?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
For high ohm resistors is normal to find lower value measured onboard.
That resistor shouldn't affect CPU.

Do you still get external video?
When you plug external monitor, I expect <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> switch to GPU output too.
Are you sure no image on internal LCD then?
Maybe missing only backlight...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: Ok thanks for letting me know that. I did check for image on the screen using a flashlight while the external monitor was connected and there is no image. The screen is completely black but external video is fine. <SIGNAL>EG_LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> are both 3.3v but <SIGNAL>EG_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> are both 0v. If the issue was with the CPU video output, shouldn't I still be getting the backlight enable voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: You may have now problem with <CHIP>U9800</CHIP>/50...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: I replaced <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> again on this board but still got the same issue. I did notice while measuring that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_GPU</SIGNAL> has 3.29v, but in diode mode, it shows as .031. I measured this on a working board and it measured 0.439. In resistance mode, it measures 60 ohm on this board and 65K ohms on a good board. Does this mean the GPU is bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
Is possible, but there are other chips connected too.
You can try removing them (one by one) and checking the change in diode mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: I removed UA950, QA800, and UA801 and checked the diode mode value of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_GPU</SIGNAL> and it was still 0.031. All the other chips on this line are not actually populated on the board so the only thing left is the capacitors, resistors and the GPU. Should I start removing caps and resistors or do you think its the GPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
Strange to have bad GPU if you get external video.

Check on external monitor if GPU, or iGPU is the active graphics.
On older models external monitor is always driven by GPU.
I didn't check any new model to see if is still the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: Yea it does appear to be using the AMD GPU when I look on the external display. Idk where to go from here. This board is really starting to get on my nerves.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
In such case dedicated GPU should pass through <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> too.
Post <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL>/EN signals value.
Check for knocked off, or moved resistors around <CHIP>U9800</CHIP>/50; especially pull-ups/downs ones.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
With the internal screen connected only, <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL>/EN are both 3.3v. When I connect the external screen, <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> goes to 0v but the enable is still 3.3v. I checked the whole board again for knocked off or moved components but I did not find anything. I did notice almost all the capacitors around <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6450</CHIP> are burnt on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> side, but this is for audio so I don't think it has anything to do with the screen. This area is close to the backlight driver though. 

I checked the resistance of all the resistors on page 89 of the schematic and they all measure correctly except for the below resistors which should all be 100k. I know high ohm resistors can measure lower on the board but I did compare to a good board and they are all 100k on the good board.

<RESISTOR>R9873</RESISTOR> - 54.6K
<RESISTOR>R9875</RESISTOR> - 67.1K
<RESISTOR>R9837</RESISTOR> - 55.1K
<RESISTOR>R9846</RESISTOR> - 55.7K
<RESISTOR>R9848</RESISTOR> - 54.7K
<RESISTOR>R9852</RESISTOR> - 55.6K
<RESISTOR>R9853</RESISTOR> - 31.3K

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> switch to 0V when connect external monitor, means <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> should allow <SIGNAL>DP_INT_EG</SIGNAL> signals to pass.
Low chance to have both <SIGNAL>DP_INT_IG</SIGNAL>/EG video outputs bad.
More probable one problem with <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>, or some component around it.
If not, connection problem with the LCD assembly.

Can you check the input/output signals at <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> with an o-scope?

Mentioned resistors are connected with <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> and point to a problem with it.
If no video signal (on o-scope) at <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> inputs, then <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> is suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Display
threads.message: I am not able to check the inputs of <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> because they only go to a ball under the CPU or GPU, but I checked all the outputs at the LCD connector with a test screen connected, and they are all 0v except for <SIGNAL>EDP_AUXCH_C_N</SIGNAL>, which is 0.98v with no wave on the o-scope. I did replace <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor since I do not have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> so that could be the issue.
